title: Bribe
data:
Certain monsters in *[Nethack](/wiki/Nethack "Nethack")* can be **bribed**. Bribery always requires that the gold to be used is in open inventory; gold in containers cannot be accessed during the transaction.

[Temple priests](/wiki/Aligned_priest "Aligned priest") [sell protection](/wiki/Protection_racket "Protection racket"). This isn't normally called bribing.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Bribing in Gehennom](#Bribing_in_Gehennom)
- [2 Bribing the Yendorian Army](#Bribing_the_Yendorian_Army)
- [3 Bribing shopkeepers](#Bribing_shopkeepers)
- [4 References](#References)

## Bribing in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom")

[Demon princes](/wiki/Demon_prince "Demon prince") will ask you for a bribe when they first notice you, if you have gold in open inventory; refusing to bribe them will turn them hostile and they will never ask for a bribe again, whereas bribing them will prompt them to disappear for good, along with their entire inventory (except the invocation items).[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

- The amount asked is normally 21-100% of your visible gold. If the demon is not in hell, or if it is a chameleon in a form of demon, it will instead ask only 1-80% of your visible gold. If your [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") is the same as demon's, the amount will be half of this. The amount is always rounded down.
- If you have no gold in open inventory, or have so little that the amount above is zero, the demon prince will be hostile and will not ask for a bribe.
- If you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into a demon, the demon prince will remain peaceful without requiring a bribe[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) and will attempt to teleport away.
- If the prince is carrying the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor"), they will ask for more gold than you have, thus ensuring they will not disappear from the game with the Amulet.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)
- If you are carrying the Amulet of Yendor at creation time, the demon cannot be bribed. Carrying the amulet at the time you meet the demon has no effect.
- Wielding [Excalibur](/wiki/Excalibur "Excalibur") at demon creation time or near the demon prevents bribing.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)
- You cannot bribe a demon if you are [deaf](/wiki/Deaf "Deaf").
- Chaotic demons cannot be bribed. [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus") is the only one waiting in a lair.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Wielding [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane") now prevents you from bribing demons as Excalibur does.

## Bribing the Yendorian Army

[Soldiers](/wiki/Soldier "Soldier") can be bribed by by throwing a suitable amount of gold at them, turning them [peaceful](/wiki/Peaceful "Peaceful"). On the [Castle](/wiki/Castle "Castle") level, it is occasionally helpful to bribe a soldier to block a corridor for you, as hostile monsters will not route past peaceful ones.[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) The required amount is:

![
X + \frac{G + 1d5 \times {\mathit XL}}{{\mathit Cha}}
](/images/math/3/2/5/3254da303d4ecee3a7fd1cd4305eab28.png)

![G](/images/math/d/f/c/dfcf28d0734569a6a693bc8194de62bf.png) here represents the amount of gold you have in your open inventory; ![X](/images/math/0/2/1/02129bb861061d1a052c592e2dc6b383.png) is 150 for soldiers, 250 for sergeants, 500 for lieutenants, and 750 for captains. They only have a two in three chance of accepting the offer.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

If you can't bag or drop your extra gold, the optimal amount to throw is:

![
\frac{(Cha \times X) + {\mathit (4 \times XL) + G}}{{1 + Cha}} + Cha
](/images/math/4/0/f/40f8b90fceeb77f2efb579a5cc9d1e60.png)

The [Watch](/wiki/Watch "Watch") cannot be pacified by bribing in this manner despite being [mercenaries](/wiki/Mercenaries "Mercenaries"), although you can pacify them by other means (see the section below in particular).

## Bribing shopkeepers

Angry [shopkeepers](/wiki/Shopkeeper "Shopkeeper") will also accept bribes via the #[chat](/wiki/Chat "Chat") command, or by throwing the necessary amount of gold at them. If you can afford the asking price, the shopkeeper will become peaceful again.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

- Pacifying a shopkeeper this way will also pacify any watchmen or watch captains on the level (usually [Minetown](/wiki/Minetown "Minetown"), but also some variants' [shopping mall](/wiki/Special_level_\(SLASH%27EM\)#Mall "Special level (SLASH'EM)")).
- Beware of throwing gold at peaceful shopkeepers: they have a chance of becoming hostile, as with any other peaceful monster pelted with money.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [monmove.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 399](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/monmove.c#line399 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/monmove.c"): *The amount requested never exceeds the amount in your wallet; you may offer less than the requested amount, but in this case the bribe may fail.*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [sounds.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 761](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/sounds.c#line761 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/sounds.c")
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [minion.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 161](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/minion.c#line161 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/minion.c")
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [minion.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 183](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/minion.c#line183 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/minion.c")
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [mongone](/wiki/Source:Mon.c#mongone "Source:Mon.c") in [mon.c](/wiki/Source:Mon.c "Source:Mon.c")
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [makemon.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 1050](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/makemon.c#line1050 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/makemon.c"): *check at level generation time*
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [minion.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 147](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/minion.c#line147 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/minion.c"): *check at meeting time*
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [dokick.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 319](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dokick.c#line319 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dokick.c")

From NetHackWiki

Certain monsters in Nethack can be bribed. Bribery always requires that the gold to be used is in open inventory; gold in containers cannot be accessed during the transaction.

Temple priests sell protection. This isn't normally called bribing.

  • 2 Bribing the Yendorian Army

Bribing in Gehennom

Demon princes will ask you for a bribe when they first notice you, if you have gold in open inventory; refusing to bribe them will turn them hostile and they will never ask for a bribe again, whereas bribing them will prompt them to disappear for good, along with their entire inventory (except the invocation items).[1][2]

  • The amount asked is normally 21-100% of your visible gold. If the demon is not in hell, or if it is a chameleon in a form of demon, it will instead ask only 1-80% of your visible gold. If your alignment is the same as demon's, the amount will be half of this. The amount is always rounded down.
  • If you have no gold in open inventory, or have so little that the amount above is zero, the demon prince will be hostile and will not ask for a bribe.
  • If you are polymorphed into a demon, the demon prince will remain peaceful without requiring a bribe[3] and will attempt to teleport away.
  • If the prince is carrying the Amulet of Yendor, they will ask for more gold than you have, thus ensuring they will not disappear from the game with the Amulet.[4][5]
  • If you are carrying the Amulet of Yendor at creation time, the demon cannot be bribed. Carrying the amulet at the time you meet the demon has no effect.
  • Wielding Excalibur at demon creation time or near the demon prevents bribing.[6][7]
  • You cannot bribe a demon if you are deaf.
  • Chaotic demons cannot be bribed. Orcus is the only one waiting in a lair.
